### Subsetting 

---

1. [] :
    - always return an object of the same class as the original; 
    - can be used to selected more than one element.
2. [[]] : 
    - is used to extract element of a list or data frames; 
    - it can be only be used to extract a single element 
    - and the class of return object will not necessary to be list or data frame.
3. $
    - is used to extract element of a list or data frames by name
    - semantics are similar to hat of [[]]
    
#### Baisc 

##### numeric index

```R
> x <- c('a','b','c','c','d','a')
> x
[1] "a" "b" "c" "c" "d" "a"
> x[1]
[1] "a"
> x[2]
[1] "b"
> x[1:4]
[1] "a" "b" "c" "c"
> x[4:1]
[1] "c" "c" "b" "a"
```

##### logical index

```R
> x [x>'a']
[1] "b" "c" "c" "d"
> u <- x>'a'
> u
[1] FALSE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE
> x[u]
[1] "b" "c" "c" "d"
```

#### Lists

List:

```R
> x <- list(foo=1:4, bar=0.6)
> x
$foo
[1] 1 2 3 4

$bar
[1] 0.6
```

[] return the same class, so x[1] still list

```R
> x[1]
$foo
[1] 1 2 3 4
```

[[]] return the single element of the list

```R
> x[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3 4
> x[['foo']]
[1] 1 2 3 4
> name <- 'foo'
> x[name] #return list
$foo
[1] 1 2 3 4
> x[[name]] #return element
[1] 1 2 3 4
```

$ return the elment associate with the name

```R
> x$bar
[1] 0.6
> x$foo
[1] 1 2 3 4
```

other

```R
> x <- list(foo='hello' ,bar=0.6, baz='world')
> x[c(1,3)]
$foo
[1] "hello"
$baz
[1] "world"
```

[] compare [[]]

```R
> x[['bar']] # return element
[1] 0.6
> x['bar']   # return list
$bar
[1] 0.6
```

subsetting nested elements of a list

```R
> x <- list(a =list(12,13,14), b=list(3.14, 2.18))
> x[[1]][[1]]
[1] 12
> x[[2]][[1]]
[1] 3.14
> x[[c(1,2)]]
[1] 13
> x[[c(2,1)]]
[1] 3.14
```

#### Matrices

- first index: row
- second index: column

create 2*3 matrix

```R
> x <- matrix(1:6, nrow=2, ncol=3)
> x
     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    3    5
[2,]    2    4    6
```

example of subset

```R
> x[1,2]
[1] 3
> x[2,1]
[1] 2
> x[1,]
[1] 1 3 5
> x[,2]
[1] 3 4
```

subset of matrix still be matrix

```R
> x[1,2, drop=FALSE]
     [,1]
[1,]    3
```

```R
> x[1,, drop=FALSE]
     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    3    5
```

#### Partial Matching

create list 

```R
> x <- list(abdababga = 1:4)
> x
$abdababga
[1] 1 2 3 4
```

```R
> x$a
[1] 1 2 3 4
```

```R
> x[['a']]
NULL
> x[['a', exact=F]]
[1] 1 2 3 4
```
